articles.headline: Rick Perry Hones His Image as ‘Texas Miracle’ Fades
articles.snippet: The backers of former Gov. Rick Perry say his policies spurred jobs, but many economists contend that differences in state policies play a limited role in fueling growth.
articles.abstract: The backers of former Gov. Rick Perry say his policies spurred jobs, but many economists contend that differences in state policies play a limited role in fueling growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Not long ago, what former Gov. Rick Perry and other conservatives like to call “the Texas Miracle” — the booming Texas economy — looked like a potential steppingstone to national office. But as Mr. Perry jumps into the ever-widening race for the Republican presidential nomination, his state’s economic performance appears considerably less miraculous.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Apple Takes On a Market Full of Streaming Services
articles.snippet: The company will be entering a crowded market, but its size and reach will be to its advantage.
articles.abstract: The company will be entering a crowded market, but its size and reach will be to its advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to streaming music, is Apple arriving too late or right on time?

articles.headline: Inequality Troubles Americans Across Party Lines, Times/CBS Poll Finds
articles.snippet: A strong majority says steps need to be taken urgently to assure that the fruits of the economic recovery are shared among income classes, according to the New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.abstract: A strong majority says steps need to be taken urgently to assure that the fruits of the economic recovery are shared among income classes, according to the New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans are broadly concerned about inequality of wealth and income despite an economy that has improved by most measures, a sentiment that is already driving the 2016 presidential contest, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and Dalia Sussman

articles.headline: Using Violence and Persuasion, ISIS Makes Political Gains
articles.snippet: Amid punishing American-backed airstrikes, the Islamic State militants have used a strategy of persuasion and violence to advance in Iraq and Syria.
articles.abstract: Amid punishing American-backed airstrikes, the Islamic State militants have used a strategy of persuasion and violence to advance in Iraq and Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Days after seizing the Syrian desert city of Palmyra, Islamic State militants blew up the notorious Tadmur Prison there, long used by the Syrian government to detain and torture political prisoners.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Tim Arango

articles.headline: Walmart Adjusts the Thermostat to Warm Worker Relations
articles.snippet: The effort to project an image of a more caring employer includes adjusting the air-conditioning, relaxing the dress code and jazzing up store music.
articles.abstract: The effort to project an image of a more caring employer includes adjusting the air-conditioning, relaxing the dress code and jazzing up store music.
articles.lead_paragraph: BENTONVILLE, Ark. — When the weather gets sultry here at company headquarters, Walmart workers everywhere brace for an icy blast.

articles.headline: Why a Presidential Campaign Is the Ultimate Start-Up
articles.snippet: Managing a presidential candidate’s campaign is a lot like steering a hot tech start-up through its early years, and if successful, having to scale up very fast.
articles.abstract: Managing a presidential candidate’s campaign is a lot like steering a hot tech start-up through its early years, and if successful, having to scale up very fast.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new start-up in Brooklyn Heights has 80,000 square feet of freshly leased office space, computer boxes used as improvised furniture and enormous ambitions.

articles.headline: Tsipras and Greece Buy Time From I.M.F.
articles.snippet: Amid tense negotiations, Athens invoked a little-used option to defer June payments to the International Monetary Fund until the end of the month.
articles.abstract: Amid tense negotiations, Athens invoked a little-used option to defer June payments to the International Monetary Fund until the end of the month.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — As it tries to negotiate a new bailout deal with creditors, Greece got some breathing room on Thursday by deferring a series of debt payments until the end of the month.
articles.byline: By Niki Kitsantonis and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Hunting for Hackers, N.S.A. Secretly Expands Internet Spying at U.S. Border
articles.snippet: Searching for evidence of computer hacking originating abroad, the Obama administration has stepped up warrantless monitoring, documents show.
articles.abstract: Searching for evidence of computer hacking originating abroad, the Obama administration has stepped up warrantless monitoring, documents show.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Without public notice or debate, the Obama administration has expanded the National Security Agency‘s warrantless surveillance of Americans’ international Internet traffic to search for evidence of malicious computer hacking, according to classified N.S.A. documents.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage, Julia Angwin, Jeff Larson and Henrik Moltke
